Expectation1: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation1: A noise complaint has circulated on the floor, and a face-to-face meeting in the lobby calls for extra courtesy.
Situation2: They spot a child struggling in the deep end where swimming is restricted.
Story: I was on my way to the pool for my lifeguard shift when I saw Mrs. Lee, my neighbor from down the hall, waiting in the lobby. She smiled, but I could sense tension—everyone had heard about the noise complaint, and I knew she expected a friendly, neighborly chat to smooth things over. I tried to keep my tone light and polite, just as a good neighbor should, even though I was already running late. As we exchanged pleasantries, I glanced through the glass doors and saw a child flailing in the deep end of the pool—right where swimming was off-limits. My training screamed at me to act immediately, to enforce the rules and ensure safety, but Mrs. Lee was still talking, expecting my full attention and warmth. My heart pounded as I stood there, torn between being the attentive neighbor she needed and the vigilant lifeguard the child desperately required.
